articles.title: EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: This document is the November 1989 issue (Volume 1, Number 11) of "EPHEMERIS," the official publication of the San Jose Astronomical Association. It serves as a newsletter for the astronomy club, likely containing updates, event schedules, or observing reports from that period.

articles.title: DESKTOP PUBLISHING COMES TO THE EPHEMERIS!
articles.summary: The SJAA's Ephemeris publication has undergone a significant format change, now utilizing desktop publishing software and laser printers for a more professional appearance. This month's issue also welcomes back Jay Freeman's "Celestial Tourist Speaks" column, featuring observations with small telescopes. Members are encouraged to provide feedback on the new layout.

articles.title: THIS MONTH! A VOYAGE OF DISCOVERY AT NEPTUNE
articles.summary: This article announces two significant astronomical events in November: a General Meeting on November 18th and the 1989 AANC Astronomical Conference on November 18th and 19th. The General Meeting will feature Dr. Jeff Cuzzi presenting images and findings from Voyager's recent historic flyby of Neptune and its moon Triton. The AANC Conference will host multiple expert speakers discussing diverse topics including new Neptune results, solar astronomy, astrophotography techniques, and will include contests, exhibits, and presentations by amateur astronomers.

articles.title: SCHOOL STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: The SJAA is experiencing a significant increase in schoolyard star party requests, leading to a crucial need for more volunteer observers. The article highlights successful past events, including a busy week in October and ongoing Branham Lane star parties, and encourages members to participate in upcoming sessions.

articles.title: ASTRONOMY AND TELESCOPE MAKING RENEWALS -- LAST REMINDER
articles.summary: This is a final reminder for members to renew their subscriptions to Astronomy and Telescope Making magazines through Jim Van Nuland. Astronomy magazine will cost $14.00 and Telescope Making will cost $8.00. Instructions are provided for both current SJAA subscribers and independent subscribers whose subscriptions expire in 1990.

articles.title: NOVEMBER 18TH 8 PM DR. JEFF CUZZI - NASA THE NEPTUNE FLYBY!
articles.summary: The document announces a general meeting on November 18th featuring Dr. Jeff Cuzzi from NASA, who will speak about the Neptune Flyby. It also lists a comprehensive schedule of astronomy-related events for November and December, including various public and club star parties, board meetings, and another general meeting.

articles.title: SJAA EVENTS THIS MONTH
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) has scheduled multiple star parties for November, including events at Grant Ranch County Park and Henry Coe State Park, along with public star parties in November and December. Additionally, the club's monthly Board meeting on November 11th, open to all members, will be followed by an indoor star party and an opportunity to interact with club officers.

articles.title: METEORS THIS MONTH
articles.summary: The article highlights that November will feature several meteor showers, noting that while most will be minor, one is expected to be major. It also suggests that some showers might be extinct, encouraging readers to engage in active meteor plotting to determine their current status.

articles.title: NOVEMBER METEOR SUMMARY
articles.summary: This article outlines astronomical events and observing opportunities for November, including major meteor showers like the Leonids and a lunar occultation of the Beehive cluster. It also provides practical guides for amateur astronomers, such as calculations for telescope limits, a deep-sky challenge targeting NGC 7252, and simple instructions for locating Neptune.

articles.title: JUPITER'S CHANGING FACE
articles.summary: Astronomers Barry Lutz and Craig Gullugson at Lowell Observatory have observed significant changes in Jupiter's appearance. They noted that the South Equatorial Belt has faded in visible light but remains prominent at longer wavelengths, while the Great Red Spot, indistinct visibly, stands out in deep red and near-infrared light. Observers are encouraged to continue monitoring Jupiter for further changes as it brightens in the morning sky.

articles.title: NOVA SCUTI 1989
articles.summary: Astronomer Paul Wild discovered Nova Scuti 1989 on September 20th in Scutum, appearing at 10th magnitude. Observations indicate it is a couple of weeks past maximum light, having brightened by roughly 13 magnitudes. Located at R.A. = 18h 49m 39s, Dec. = -6d 11m 16s, it is currently visible to observers using large binoculars or small telescopes.

articles.title: AMAZING NEW ASTRONOMY PRODUCTS DUE SOON!!!
articles.summary: This article, sourced from an unnamed publication (possibly SJAA EPHEMERIS), teases upcoming and exciting new astronomy products from the R&D departments of several lesser-known astronomical manufacturing companies. These products are expected to be released soon and are anticipated to greatly enhance user enjoyment of astronomy.

articles.title: SJAA EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: The article, titled 'SJAA EPHEMERIS,' presents a humorous and largely fictional list of astronomical equipment and accessories. It features an array of whimsical items like a 'black hole illuminator' and a 'Hubble Space Telescope decoder ring,' alongside more plausible-sounding but exaggerated aids. The content appears to be a satirical take on advanced or aspirational observing technology, likely from an astronomical association.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: ASTRO ADS is a free classifieds section for non-commercial advertisers to sell astronomically related products or services. This particular issue features numerous listings for used telescopes, mounts, and a wide array of accessories from various brands like Meade, Celestron, and Lumicon, with prices ranging from $150 to $11,000.

articles.title: SPACE PROGRAM UPDATE
articles.summary: This article provides updates on several space programs: the Galileo spacecraft launch was rescheduled for October 17th, detailing its multi-year journey to Jupiter with gravity assists and asteroid flybys. The Hubble Space Telescope was quietly moved from Lockheed, while the Space Station program faces significant design changes and delays (completion to 1999) due to budget cuts, impacting power systems, thrusters, manned capability, and international module delivery. Furthermore, the article outlines necessary space station modifications to support a future lunar base and Mars initiative.

articles.title: THE CELESTIAL TOURIST SPEAKS
articles.summary: Jay Reynolds Freeman recounts his experience at a sparsely attended but exceptionally clear SJAA Star Party at Fremont Peak. He details various observations, including M33, Pleiades, Uranus, and a challenging detection of Stefan's Quintet with a small aperture. The highlight was a successful, meticulous re-attempt at visually observing the Sculptor System, a faint dwarf galaxy, using a 5-inch refractor and binoculars, confirming its position.

articles.title: GREAT RED SPOT
articles.summary:
# GREAT RED SPOT
*- JIM VAN NULAND*

Continuing observations of Jupiter and its Great Red Spot have verified the surprising findings of last month. The South Equatorial Belt is exceedingly faint or ab...

articles.title: JUPITER'S RED SPOT
articles.summary: This article provides a schedule of predicted transit times for Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) across the central meridian for November and December, expressed in PST. It clarifies that these times are corrected for optimal viewing and advises observers to conduct observations approximately an hour before and after the listed times. The author also includes an apology for a previous scheduling error caused by confusion over daylight saving time.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: This article provides updates on three comets for November: Comet Okazaki-Levy-Rudenko (1989r) is expected to be visible in the morning sky, possibly to the unaided eye, and will have a close conjunction with the Moon on November 24th. Comet Helin-Roman (1989s), discovered in September, is now fading after its closest approach to the sun in August. Finally, Periodic Comet Wild 2 (1989) was recovered at magnitude 20 and is anticipated to become visible to amateur astronomers next year.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: A study analyzing 45 amateur visual comet discoveries from 1975-1988 found an average elongation of 62 degrees from the Sun, noting that comets closer to the Sun upon discovery tend to be brighter. Visual sightings are impossible within 20 degrees of the Sun due to glare, and fainter comets (below magnitude 10) are difficult to spot within 40 degrees. Extreme elongations, both very close to and opposite the Sun, are typically found through photographic surveys, solar eclipses, or satellite monitoring.

articles.title: OFFICERS AND BOARD OF DIRECTORS
articles.summary: This document lists the current officers and board of directors, including their names, titles (President, Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary, Editor, and Directors), and respective contact phone numbers. It provides a directory of key personnel within an organization.

articles.title: COMET EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: This document provides an ephemeris for Comet Okazaki-Levy-Rudenko (1989r) for a period spanning from late October to early December. It lists daily celestial coordinates (Right Ascension and Declination for both 1950 and 2000 epochs), elongation from the Sun, sky visibility indicator, and estimated visual magnitude. This data is essential for observers tracking the comet's position and brightness.

articles.title: EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: EPHEMERIS is a monthly publication by the San Jose Astronomical Association that encourages its members to submit articles. Submissions must be typed and sent to the editor, John P. Gleason, by the 12th of the previous month for consideration.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), detailing various membership options including standard, standard with Sky & Telescope subscription, and junior memberships, along with their respective fees. It provides instructions for submitting the application and payment to the SJAA treasurer, Jack Peterson, via mail or in person at a meeting. The document also includes information about the SJAA's publication, 'SJAA Ephemeris', and its non-profit mailing details.

articles.title: THE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION OF NORTHERN CALIFORNIA
articles.summary: The Astronomical Association of Northern California announced its 1989 Annual Astronomical Conference. The event is scheduled for November 18th and 19th, from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., at the Lawrence Hall of Science, University of California, Berkeley.

articles.title: FEATURING:
articles.summary: This document outlines a series of presentations by notable figures in astronomy and space science, covering a wide range of topics. These include a detailed analysis of Neptune results, amateur solar astronomy, an expedition to observe aurora, a comparison of photographic emulsions and electronic cameras for astrophotography, and an examination of why most UFO reports are not alien in origin.

articles.title: ALSO...
articles.summary: This document outlines details for an upcoming astronomy conference, likely hosted by the AANC, featuring presentations by amateur astronomers, information on Northern California astronomy clubs, astronomical product displays, and an astrophotography contest and exhibit. It includes registration fees, a call for papers, and contact information, along with a registration form for the conference and an awards banquet at Shenanigans Restaurant.
